name: EV-TRAIN-MOVING-SOUNDS.MP3
description: I recorded these sounds during travelling on the Metro Line 2 in Budapest, from station Örs Vezér Tere to station Blaha Lujza tér. I started recording sounds when the train was slowing down to the second station, Pillangó utca, and the recording is ended when the train was arrived to the station 'Blaha'. If you use train simulator, you have MP3 editor and you are looking for sound effects, you may find some.This is a good chance for me to made this recording because the train always move fastly and very rarely stops in the tunnel between two stations.At the first minute when the train arrived to 'Pillangó utca' the CP engine was on and it is ideal looping sound effect. Going into the deep at 1:40, the train is going very slowly into the tunnel. At 2:16 There is another train which is going fastly on the backward railway in the tunnel. It has great echo sounds. The sound is an ideal looping sound for slow-moving, I think. At 2:48 the train was accelerating a bit and you can hear cleanly the looping motor sound. at 3:23 the train stopped in the tunnel for 20 seconds, then arrived to station Stadionok. At 4:33 it is moving to the next station, Keleti Pályaudvar. I like hearing at 4:47 and 4:55 at any time when it is going onto the rail-crossings. The station Keleti Pályaudvar is much deeper then the station Stadionok. You cannot hear the motor sounds of the train. This is a good looping example for fast-moving sound. When the train was arrived at the station the CP engine was started again and you can hear it almost clearly.

name: Sounds of a train journey #01
description: An audio recording of a train journey. You can hear the train sounds, the passengers quietly in the background and a automatic announcement. The female voice says "Bitte in Fahrtrichtung rechts aussteigen". That means: Please get off right in direction of travel. The Train is a Siemens Desiro, a Diesel Locomotive, used by the german train company Vogtlandbahn. Recorded with ZOOM H2n Handy Recorder Recording Format: WAV 48kHz/24bit Input Gain: Auto Gain Edited and exported to FLAC with Audacity. Interior of a DMU ("Desiro") of the Vogtlandbahn Photo by Sülzauge [GFDL or CC-BY-SA-3.0], via Wikimedia Commons

name: passenger train sounds - track, rail squeal, click clack, horn, crossing bells
description:
Here are some train sounds I recorded while riding a tourist railroad which had two floor passenger cars (Santa Fe Hi-Liners). I placed the microphone in the area where you cross between cars (which is on the upper level). Note that the sound of people can often be heard so sorry about that. The right microphone was closer to the sound source.

27:37 passing by RR crossing bells (and also once more before this time)
47:00 some good rail squeal around this time

recorded with a Sony ICD UX560

Leave a comment. I would love to see what you do with my sounds!

name: aLowTrain.aiff
description: This is "train.wav" by LS processed with a bunch of Karplus-Strong resonators. name: Sound Memories - Balboa Street, factory, horses, train
description: Elders of Barceloneta describing the ancient sounds of the neighborhood. Sound memories of Puri. Puri was born in Balboa Street, there was a factory before flans. On the home front were heard horses carts were gas, coal. You could hear the "cluck, cluck, cluck" of horses. Was heard from behind the train going to the dock to unload. Demonstrations train because closing the Barceloneta when this was stopped. Finally took the train in the sixties. Interview recorded in the framework of the Memoria Sonoria activities of the project Barceloneta Sonora. Zoom H4n http://barcelonetasonora.wordpress.com/

name: slow_train_2.flac
description: I was riding my bike home one night when I saw a train was coming, so I quickly set up my mics and recorded this slow train pulling out of Portland. There are lots of interesting textures and metallic sounds to be found. Recorded with AT4021's into a modified Marantz PMD661. The only editing of this file is a small fade at the start and end, a boost in volume and conversion to flac.

name: ten pm train.flac
description: At 10PM a bell at the Olympic Sculpture park informs people of the time, just after that a train passes by. All the while a fountain creates noise in the background. Once the train passes, traffic starts again. Recorded with a pair of AT4021s into a modified Marantz PMD661. The stereo image may seem shifted to the right because I was sitting directly in front of a large concrete structure that the train went behind, so most of the sound arrives from the right.

name: slow train 2 April 24 2012.flac
description:
A large freight train passes from left to right. There is quite a lot of dynamic range, particularly at the beginning, so turn it up for best results. There are several screeches and metallic scrape and other large train sounds.
Recorded with a pair of AT4021 mics into a modified Marantz PMD661 and edited with Reason.

name: Train cabin by night, wheels grind. Kazan - Yekaterinburg
description:
In cabin. Train wheels grinding the rails, odd wind howling makes a melody. Water bottles stored under the cabin seats make soft sounds. Recorded with Tascam DR-40.

I've only used the internet to facilitate human contacts. Being with actual people in actual places has always been the goal. I like it when, in the presence of real people, we don't speak for a while. We just do something that we've agreed to do together in silence. There is an agreement and we don't have to think about who we are, how we can be who we are or what it all means. Doing becomes meaning.

name: mab-train-mkh800-ms.wav
description:
This recording is part of the microphone-comparison-freight-train-wav
sample pack. 
The three samples in this series were recorded simultaneously (from
approximately the same position) with three different standard stereo
microphone arrangements: mid-side (mixed into L-R), X-Y cardioid, and
with a Jecklin disk.

The 5'34" recordings capture a long freight train (with a helicopter
flying overhead) passing approximately 10 feet in front of the
microphones (from left to right) in Berkeley, California (USA) on
September 17, 2006.

This recording was made with a pair of Sennheiser MKH-800
microphones in a mid-side configuration (inside a Rycote blimp).
The "mid" microphone was set to "wide cardioid" and the "side"
was set to "figure-8", with the array connected to a Sound Devices 744T
digital recorder at 96K/24bits.  Mixed into conventional A-B stereo in Logic Pro.


A compressed (256Kbps) MP3 version of this recording is available in the
microphone-comparison-freight-train-mp3 sample pack.

name: MR73 metro train sound (synth)
description: Sound synthesized in beepbox.co This is the sound of an MR73 rubber-tire metro train from Montreal. There is no typical train wheel sound as this train uses rubber tires instead. When departing, the train produces 3 tones (180, 240, and 360 Hz) from the current chopper, a device that controls the motor current, allowing for faster acceleration.

name: mysterious sound during the journey by train.flac
description:
mysterious sound during the journey by train

I recorded this sound in a train between stations Kozarovce - Nova bana (Slovakia). When the train passes through the track between those stations, passengers can hear sound, similar to braking truck. One friend told me the story behind this mysterious sound: Once upon a time, overnight express crashed to the truck in the rail crossing which is located between those stations. The truck was destroyed because train pushed the truck a few hundred meters away. The driver was dead and his body was not buried in its entirety. His spirit settled there and passengers have to listen to a sound of braking truck. Railwaymen supposedly rebuilded this part of a track, but the sound didn't disappear.
you can hear two different sounds. First is on a track between Nova Bana - Kozarovce, second is in the same truck but in return path. Recorded with Zoom H1 internal mic. The recording is original, I just normalized and selected the right parts.

name: IC3 train from Odense to Aarhus, Denmark, part 3 of 3
description:
The full trip from Odense to Aarhus, Denmark, in the IC3 train "Storm P". The recorder was placed with microphones up in the window facing seat in the silent zone (thus very little and istrant human voices and no privacy issues). The recording mostly consists of the sounds of the train and the speaker calls from time to time. At one point you can faintly hear the conductor ask for "Nye rejsende" (new travellers).
Due to the length of the track, it is uploaded in 3 parts. The beginning and end is missing because I had to get on and off the train. On request a GPX track of the full journey can be sent, thus geotagging every sound with meters presicion.
The first part is geotagged with the beginning of the journey.

name: Slow Moving 1-Train Part 1 (interior ambiance)
description:
The sound from inside a 1-train subway car, as it slowly moves through the tunnels between Chambers and Rector (heading southerly) in Lower Manhattan.

*If an MTA announcement is included in this recording, rights to use the announcement portion of this audio may need to be obtained from the MTA and clearance from the individual making the announcement. 
See below for attribution instructions as it concerns the recording itself.

About this series:
This audio is part of a series of ambient recordings made on January 4, 2021 in New York City. I produced these sounds during the pandemic so it's about as clean as you'll get with NYC subway ambiance.

Recorded with the on-board X-Y microphone of a Zoom H4n handheld record, for use in my feature film, FRACTALS.

To use the recording, please attribute me by including the following statement in the end credits of your film or video, or if it is an audio-based project by including the credits either spoken in audio form or in the description of the project wherever it is publicly posted: "Slow Moving 1-Train Part 1 - Recorded by Eric Norcross for the feature film, FRACTALS. Used under attribution agreement."

A really awesome sound occurs at approximately 15:35.
Recordist: Tim Kahn
Recorder: Zaxcom Maxx
Microphones: MKH8020

name: slow train from above.WAV
description:
A train headed into Portland, Oregon passes under a pedestrian bridge as it makes its way slowly to the city center. Some traffic sounds in the background. For best results turn up loud and listen on speakers with a lot of bass. But always be nice to your ears.
Recorded with Sennheiser MKH 8020 stereo pair into a modified Marantz PMD 661.

name: Diesel Train Pass by
description: Field recording of a diesel passenger train ('Pacer' operated by Northern Rail) passing by. Sorry about the quick ending, but a dog started barking and I had to cut that off as it ruined the recording. (I'll try and get the dog recording up as soon as possible) I was waiting for about 3 minutes for the train to depart from the station (see geotag) when it began to move off in the distance and passed under the pedestrian bridge over the track I recorded this on. Fair spring evening weather, I had been sick earlier on but had managed to get out to record this- thank heaven! Maybe it's a better version of my previous Train1.wav (but that was recorded somewhere else up from the station) http://freesound.org/people/kwahmah_02/sounds/250079/ Recorded 14th May 2015 with a 5th gen iPod touch. Edited with Audacity.

name: Walking into Chambers Street Station as a Train Arrives (NYC Subway)
description:
Walking into Chambers Street Station as a train arrives (possibly a 3-train). NYC Subway.

*If an MTA announcement is included in this recording, rights to use the announcement portion of this audio may need to be obtained from the MTA and clearance from the individual making the announcement. 
See below for attribution instructions as it concerns the recording itself.

About this series:
This audio is part of a series of ambient recordings made on January 4, 2021 in New York City. I produced these sounds during the pandemic so it's about as clean as you'll get with NYC subway ambiance.

Recorded with the on-board X-Y microphone of a Zoom H4n handheld record, for use in my feature film, FRACTALS.

To use the recording, please attribute me by including the following statement in the end credits of your film or video, or if it is an audio-based project by including the credits either spoken in audio form or in the description of the project wherever it is publicly posted: "Walking into Chambers Street Station as a Train Arrives - Recorded by Eric Norcross for the feature film, FRACTALS. Used under attribution agreement."

name: 2 Trains passing in short time, railroad barrier opens, 5m distance, 4 mics

Used microphones: 2x Rode M2 + Zoom H6N

name: Via Rail 693 Train Ambience
description:
The ambience of the Via Rail 693 train going North from The Pas to Churchill, Manitoba, Canada, recorded while we were all sleeping.
Heard are the occasional sound of the train's horn, and people moving in their sleep. At one point during the recording a kid sneezes and a baby is heard briefly near the end. 
I cleaned up the audio as best I could to minimize all distortions, so as to maximize the ASMR.
Dedicated to Sasha ASMR and all other Ukrainian ASMR channels.

name: mab-train-at3032-jecklin.mp3
description:
This recording is part of the microphone-comparison-freight-train-mp3
sample pack. 
The three samples in this series were recorded simultaneously (from
approximately the same position) with three different standard stereo
microphone arrangements: mid-side (mixed into L-R), X-Y cardioid, and
with a Jecklin disk.

The 5'34" recordings capture a long freight train (with a helicopter
flying overhead) passing approximately 10 feet in front of the
microphones (from left to right) in Berkeley, California (USA) on
September 17, 2006.

This recording was made with a pair of Audio-Technica AT-3032
omni-directional microphones (with Rycote "ball gag" windscreens)
mounted on a Jecklin disk and connected to a Sound Devices 744T
digital recorder at 96K/24bits.

An uncompressed 96K/24 WAV version of this recording is available in the
microphone-comparison-freight-train-wav sample pack.

name: forest far train 02 130110_00.wav
description: Far long electric locomotive freight-train passing on 700 meter from a forest in the winter. Because Holland is flat, there is almost no wind and that little wind is coming from the railway-track it takes minutes that you really can hear the humming is from a train. If you listen careful you hear the very deep hum of the train in the beginning, long before you hear the train. Listen how the high frequents of the train go first when the rain disappears in the distance. In the distance a dog barking and just a few birds like blackbird, sparrow, woodpecker just searching for food in the trees , a tit, crow and a magpie. name: mab-train-mkh800-ms.mp3
description:
This recording is part of the microphone-comparison-freight-train-mp3
sample pack. 
The three samples in this series were recorded simultaneously (from
approximately the same position) with three different standard stereo
microphone arrangements: mid-side (mixed into L-R), X-Y cardioid, and
with a Jecklin disk.

The 5'34" recordings capture a long freight train (with a helicopter
flying overhead) passing approximately 10 feet in front of the
microphones (from left to right) in Berkeley, California (USA) on
September 17, 2006.

This recording was made with a pair of Sennheiser MKH-800
microphones in a mid-side configuration (inside a Rycote blimp).
The "mid" microphone was set to "wide cardioid" and the "side"

digital recorder at 96K/24bits.  Mixed into conventional A-B stereo in Logic Pro.

An uncompressed 96K/24 WAV version of this recording is available in the
microphone-comparison-freight-train-wav sample pack.

name: Digital sport vehicle sounds- Car 1 .mp3
description: This racing vehicles recording 2 track. It might be viable for use in racing and driving video games. But over the past few years, games emerged as some of the top-selling products in video and computer gaming. The main focus in such a project would be on generating a score by merging a few sounds in the background of the soundtrack (such as bumping or breaking) with specific vehicle sound effects (such as braking). Loops would be used to affect pre-composed music, using live data to change the mix and instrumental direction (such as the dynamics, texture or timbre), or even the pitch, rhythm or tempo), Moreover, the musical soundtrack for racing vehicle gameplay could be stored in a memory card to use in digital sport car sounds unit that convenient sound effects according to the processes, which is essential to participate in the training driver by granting the user with more information. In real life, the driver has more sensory information.

name: 1 Train from Rector Street to Chambers Street (NYC Subway)
description:
A high-quality NYC subway experience: A 1-Train arrives to the Rector Street Platform, and then the recordist transitions to the inside of the rear train car, and rides to Chambers Street Station.

*If an MTA announcement is included in this recording, rights to use the announcement portion of this audio may need to be obtained from the MTA and clearance from the individual making the announcement. 
See below for attribution instructions as it concerns the recording itself.

About this series:
This audio is part of a series of ambient recordings made on January 4, 2021 in New York City. I produced these sounds during the pandemic so it's about as clean as you'll get with NYC subway ambiance.

Recorded with the on-board X-Y microphone of a Zoom H4n handheld record, for use in my feature film, FRACTALS.

To use the recording, please attribute me by including the following statement in the end credits of your film or video, or if it is an audio-based project by including the credits either spoken in audio form or in the description of the project wherever it is publicly posted: "1 Train from Rector Street to Chambers Street - Recorded by Eric Norcross for the feature film, FRACTALS. Used under attribution agreement."

name: 2 Train Arrives to Chambers Street Station
description:
A 2-train arrives to Chambers Street Station.

See below for attribution instructions as it concerns the recording itself.

About this series:
This audio is part of a series of ambient recordings made on January 4, 2021 in New York City. I produced these sounds during the pandemic so it's about as clean as you'll get with NYC subway ambiance.

Recorded with the on-board X-Y microphone of a Zoom H4n handheld record, for use in my feature film, FRACTALS.

name: Via Rail 692 Train Ambience
description:
The ambience of the Via Rail 692 train going South from Churchill to The Pas, Manitoba, Canada, recorded while we were all sleeping.
Heard are the occasional sound of the train's horn, and people moving in their sleep. A bit of chatter can be heard close to the end. 
I cleaned up the audio as best I could to minimize all distortions, so as to maximize the ASMR.
Dedicated to Sasha ASMR and all other Ukrainian ASMR channels.

name: Subway Train Arriving to Station (NYC)
description:
Sound of an NYC subway train arriving to station.

*If an MTA announcement is included in this recording, rights to use the announcement portion of this audio may need to be obtained from the MTA and clearance from the individual making the announcement. 
See below for attribution instructions as it concerns the recording itself.

About this series:
This audio is part of a series of ambient recordings made on January 4, 2021 in New York City. I produced these sounds during the pandemic so it's about as clean as you'll get with NYC subway ambiance.

Recorded with the on-board X-Y microphone of a Zoom H4n handheld record, for use in my feature film, FRACTALS.

To use the recording, please attribute me by including the following statement in the end credits of your film or video, or if it is an audio-based project by including the credits either spoken in audio form or in the description of the project wherever it is publicly posted: "Subway Train Arriving to Station - Recorded by Eric Norcross for the feature film, FRACTALS. Used under attribution agreement."

name: Sound Memories - Companies, factories, train, tram
description: Elders of Barceloneta describing the ancient sounds of the neighborhood. Sound memories of José Maria Marquez. In Barceloneta had two large companies which now no longer exist: "El Vulcano", where ships repaired, at the end of the ride, and "La Maquinista" where did the trains. In Maquinista street train passed. Those who went to work in the city had to jump the train because he was standing too long In the market square there was a civil guard barracks. José tells us an accident that happened to the tram of Pueblo Nuevo - 36. This tram one morning collided with a train, and to not see the disaster train blocked the newspaper papers. There was also the manufacture of gas, "La Catalana" where demonstrations were made to remove it. Interview recorded in the framework of the Memoria Sonoria activities of the project Barceloneta Sonora. Zoom H4n http://barcelonetasonora.wordpress.com/

name: mab-train-at3032-jecklin.wav
description:
This recording is part of the microphone-comparison-freight-train-wav
sample pack. 
The three samples in this series were recorded simultaneously (from
approximately the same position) with three different standard stereo
microphone arrangements: mid-side (mixed into L-R), X-Y cardioid, and
with a Jecklin disk.

The 5'34" recordings capture a long freight train (with a helicopter
flying overhead) passing approximately 10 feet in front of the
microphones (from left to right) in Berkeley, California (USA) on
September 17, 2006.

This recording was made with a pair of Audio-Technica AT-3032
omni-directional microphones (with Rycote "ball gag" windscreens)
mounted on a Jecklin disk and connected to a Sound Devices 744T
digital recorder at 96K/24bits.

A compressed (256Kbps) MP3 version of this recording is available in the
microphone-comparison-freight-train-mp3 sample pack.

name: Train/Container - Sliding Door
description:
A sliding door I created for the film I mixed, which I used the bottle-pop sound in as well. 

To make this sound, I recorded different sliding doors, wardrobes, cupboards etc. to get the slide of the train door and then for the opening of the door I recorded the steel door on my garage, which was really useful in getting the colossal size of the door. 

This sound can be used in any context, but I found this sounds better if it was used in the context of a sliding train door from the 1940's, like I used it for, or if you had a film with a huge metal container and you needed the sound of the opening of the container door. I will upload the sound of just the clang of the door if that's suits everyone better.

If you do use this, please credit me and comment how you've used it. I would love to hear how this has benefited everyone. If you have a link to the work you've used it in, I'd love to see!

Thanks,

Bowesy

name: Steam Train.WAV
description: Drei Annen Hohne is the name of a small settlement within the municipal area of Wernigerode in Saxony-Anhalt, Germany. The place is located about 9 km (5.6 mi) southwest of the town within the Harz mountains, on the northeastern edge of the Harz National Park. It is accessible from the road from Wernigerode to Schierke, an eastern branch–off leads to Elbingerode. Drei Annen Hohne is also a stop on the narrow gauge Harz Railway line from Wernigerode to Nordhausen, as well as of the Brocken Railway, which branches off south of the station. Well, I arrived just in time to see a train arrive and leave a wee while later and even managed to record the sound with a Sony PCM M10 Recorder, but it was nearly to late to get the recorder out.

Well, it is soo easy to do them, unless you have some noisy fellow travellers. Mind you, it is soo far away from "The Murder on the Orient Express" sound.

description: Electric train over steel river bridge 140 km/h. Here the bells. 100-200 metre away on the river. Recorded on the Maasboulevard at the Maas River in 's-Hertogenbosch in the Netherlands. It's a warm evening and the sun has just set. Youngsters having fun at on the waterfront. The last birds are heard. Setting: Boulevard with embankment on 100m from river. Boulevard on 10m behind. Left the steel railway-bridge. Right the constant humming of the busy Highway A2. Mics in direction of the river. More at this boulevard today / More at this boulevard trough the year Date/time: June 29th 2022, 22:22 PM. Sunset 9:49 PM Weather: 23-21c, clouds 50-53%, wind NE2 NE1 bft with gusts to 15-7 km/h, 1012 hPa, humidity 69-70%. name: Amtrak Crescent and Commuter Train, Left to Right
description:
Stereo mic is pointed 45-degrees to the left, the direction of the oncoming trains. Begins with ambient sounds, including birds and a nearby idling diesel locomotive engine to the right. A retaining wall just beyond the heavy rail tracks intensifies the sound of the Amtrak train. The light rail track, Atlanta's MARTA system, is elevated and without such a wall.

 :25 Peak locomotive
 :26 Cars pass by
 :35 End of train, then ambience

 :51 Peak
 :54 End of train
1:05 Return to ambience
1:09 End

name: 81-720 Yauza TISU (Current chopper) sound
description: Thyristor-impulse control system (TISU), or current chopper sound from an 81-720 "Yauza" subway train car. These train cars were used in the Moscow Metro until 2019 and produced this distinctive hum when accelerating or braking. This sound was made in beepbox.co using FM and pulse width modulation. Curiously, some freezers in large stores such as Costco produce a similarly pitched 200Hz hum when in operation.

And a little bit of the typical klok-klok sound you can hear in trains. A radio plays in the background and doors bang shut. I was looking perpendicular to the train, so you can hear the stereo of sounds coming from left to right.

name: train from Oksboel.wav
description:
Travelling by train from Oksbøl to Varde, two small towns located on the west coast of Denmark. This recording include the sound of people getting on and of the train. Doors being opened and closed, de- and acceleration of the train, the "go-signal" for the train to move on. The steward is making sure people know what station is next, via the speakers. There's some talk from passengers, phonecalls, footsteps and your every day travel-by-train noises. This train is a diesel powered engine Y-train, delivered to the Danish railways (DSB) in the period from 1965 to 1984, and is still running on various locations such as Varde-Oksbøl-Nr. Nebel.

This was recorded with a TSM PR1 portable digital recorder, with external stereo microphones. Edited in Audacity 1.3.5-beta on ubuntu 8.04.2 linux.

name: 81-717 BPSN hum sounds (many variants)
description: 300Hz electrical hum heard on 81-717 metro trains, found commonly in Eastern European subway systems. (Moscow, Saint-Petersburg, Kyiv, Budapest, Prague, Warsaw, and Sofia metros, to name a few). This is produced by the BPSN-5U2 converter (BPSN stands for auxiliary power supply block), a set of two static inverters that convert 750V (or 825V) DC from the third rail to 80V DC for the onboard control systems in the cabin, and 220V AC for the interior lights. One of the converters produces a 300Hz tone, the other produces a 200Hz tone. On later trains, the 200Hz tone is inaudible due to the replacement of the secondary inverter. Later 81-717 trains have had these power supplies replaced with quieter BPSN-5U2M or BBE units, or by completely silent BPN-115 and DIP power supplies. These are several variants of the sound, as heard in different cities. Made in beepbox.co

name: train on 100-200-400-800 meter.flac
description: Practice in field-recording lesson 1. No theory, that is for wikipedia, not that I am a 'know it all'. sound and distance We 'take the train' as subject for this lesson. 4 recordings of a train passing a steel bridge. We double the distance to the train every recording; 100m 200m 400m and 800m. What are the changes: 1] The further you are from the subject (train) the better you hear the background. 2] The closer you are on the subject (train) the better you hear the higher frequency's of it. Listen a hundred times, take your recorder and try this yourselves. And yes there is a lot more, but maybe that on an other lesson. What difference do you hear more? Give your comment. Tip of the day: The success of a good (field-)recording is in the first few seconds. To hear you first have to listen When you use this sound it would be nice if you spent a voluntarily donation to freesound. YOU ALWAYS HAVE TO CREDIT/ATTRIBUTE me (klankbeeld) and freesound.org in your work if you use this sound. Do it like this: sound from http://www.freesound.org/people/klankbeeld/ Do not use an indirect link.

name: tua-mirandela_train_arrival_march2007.wav
description:
Arrival of a train to Mirandela (Trás-os-Montes, Portugal) from Tua station (Douro-Tua Line) at the beginning of March 2007. This train is running one the most beautiful narrow gauge train lines in Europe, the Tua Line.
Notice the sharp distinct noise of the train wheels stepping on the rails joints and the friction noise on the tracks junction, as the carriage passes by with the engine roaring.
You can ear at the background  in the beginning the sound of the railroad gates bells ringing, a rooster, 2 different sets of birds and a dog barking constantly. There is also some noise created by my feet as I step in the gravel between the tracks.
This sound was recorded using a MZ-NH700 MD, via MIC-IN with a cheap condenser microphone.

name: Coronavirus in sound Herautstraat 200504_0171.wav
description: Take 1. Compare the sound in one and the same location. One recording is from May 2019 and the other from May 2020. One recording is without covid19. The other is during covid19. How I did compare; On May 13, 2019 I made an audio recording from thirteen minutes past seven in the evening. On May 4, 2020, I made a sound recording at the same time of the evening. I put these two tracks together exactly in time in Audacity. I adjusted the sound level of each track to the sparks that the electric trains make when they pass from one energy network to another. That is precisely in front of the microphone. Then I looked where the quietest parts of both sound recordings coincided. I used these three minutes for the comparison. In this audio file you hear the sound change every fifteen seconds. The audio file starts with the corona-free part in 2019. Both original audio files can be found below. 2019: https://freesound.org/people/klankbeeld/sounds/469990/ 2020: https://freesound.org/people/klankbeeld/sounds/516742/ picture 2019 picture 2020 Date/time 2019: May 13th Monday 2019, 7.13 pm Date/time 2020: May 4th Monday 2020, 7.13 pm Weather 2019: 15c, clear sky, wind NE 3bft with gusts to 30km/h, 1037 hPa, humidity 34%. name: FROPPIER_Mickaël_2019_2020_Train.wav
description:
This sound was made with Audacity. The goal was to create a train sound.

First, I recorded a sound of a spoon turning in an empty cup of tea during 7sec. 
Then, I tried to play with the rhythm of the sound : I copy-pasted this sound 7 times under the principal track and I shifted all the copies with the tool "time slip" with different shift (before or after the principal track). After that, I mixed all the tracks in one.

To get this sound more realistic, I changed the pitch of the track (-10) and added a reverb (7%). Because the amplitude was really low, I amplified the sound, but not beyond 0db.

name: aluna train
description: This was recorded as foley for a sound design / composition contract I took for a theatre company. We needed a train sound to signify crates of dead soldiers being shipped back from the front lines, to be processed and fed to soldiers holding encampants behind the lines. It was recorded in an arcade adjoining outbuildings of a factory converted to studio and office spaces. I excused myself from rehearsal to catch the recording shortly after learning a woman I'd been seeing for about a year was through with our relationship. I won an award in composition and sound design for the work I did for the play.

name: LS_33918_PH_TrainLRT.wav
description:
Short ride in LRt, Manila, Philippines (Binaural). 
This Binaural recording has been made in LRT (light rail transit), which is one of the two metropolitan train network available in Manila (Philippines). You can hear different sounds from the train, like doors opening and closing, sound from the engine, from the rails, from the brakes, etc... On the left side, a young lady was calling someone with her mobile phone. 
Recorded in March 2018, with an Olympus LS-3 and a Roland CS-10em binaural microphones/earphones. 
Fade in/out and high pass filter 80Hz -6dB/oct applied in Audacity.

name: Stockholm commuter train from platform.wav
description:
A Stockholm, Sweden commuter rail X60 train (Alstom Coradia Nordic) on the then J35 (Bålsta - Nynäshamn) line arriving at and leaving from the Älvsjö station. It was a cold day, if I recall correctly between -10 to -20°C (-5 to 15°F) and there was about 1 or 2 centimeters (1/4 to 1/2 inch) of powdery snow.

00:00 Warning signal at crossing (for commuter train employees only) with train arriving in background.
00:21 Footsteps in cold thin snow layer
00:25 Squealing as the train comes to a stop
00:36 Doors opening
00:41 Driver announcing that the train will depart for Stockholm central station and Bålsta station
00:55 Warning sound before doors are closing and more footsteps
00:58 Doors closing
01:11 Squealing as the train start to roll

Recorded Friday December 18, 2009, 10:01 am (UTC + 1 h), with the built in mic of a Canon Digital IXUS 950 IS camera (which could be used to record audio only). File straight off from the camera with the exception of iD3 tags added with foobar2000 v1.3.4.
